CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems, Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process Institute of Process Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Synthesis of cyclic carbonates from cheap and reusable urea is of great importance, but it is still an immense challenge to obtain highly efficient catalysts using relatively less metal-containing catalysts for this route due to conventional metal salt catalysts with established structure. Herein, a series of eco-friendly ionic liquids (ILs) with different cationic structures were adopted as efficient catalysts for the reaction of urea alcoholysis. By regulating the cation chain lengths, different lewis acid centers of imidazolium-based ILs with chain lengths from C2 to C16 were constructed. The IL with a moderate side chain (OmimCl/ZnCl2) exhibited better catalytic performance and the yield of ethylene carbonate (EC) could reach 96% percent with less metal-containing catalyst at lower diols/urea molar ratio conditions. Through exploring the structure-activity relationships of cationic structure and anionic speciation, it was illustrated that the inductive effect of cation in ILs had important influences on the synthesis of [Zn2Cl5]−. Additionally, the appearance of the [Zn2Cl5]−, which has been proved with pyridine spectroscopic could strengthen the lewis acidity of ILs to obtain high catalytic activity, this could avoid excessive metal-containing in ILs. Based on the experimental results and DFT calculations, an IL anion-cation synergistic catalytic mechanism has been proposed. Thus, the use of ILs opens up a new green avenue and provides a preliminary basis of CO2 utilization. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ionic liquids Urea alcoholysis Anionic speciation Synergistic catalysis 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an ideal renewable and environmentally friendly C1 source [1–3]. In response to the ever-increasing greenhouse effect, numerous published research strategies have been proposed. CO2 capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) has evoked great interest in the past few decades, which is therefore regarded as one of the most promising strategies to alleviate the energy and environmental crisis [4,5]. Urea, a typical product of the CO2 industry, has attracted more and more attention due to its transformation into cyclic carbonates with diols (Scheme 1a). The urea alcoholysis reaction is superior in some aspects due to its mild reaction conditions, low environmental hazard, accessible raw materials and high safe reaction process compared to other cyclic carbonates synthesis methods [6–8]. For example, ethylene carbonate (EC) can be obtained by urea alcoholysis, while ammonia can be reused as the starting material for urea recycling. In addition, EC can be used for a variety of applications in different fields, such as the electrolyte of lithium-ion batteries [9], raw material of polycarbonates [10], aprotic polar solvents [11] and intermediates [6] for many chemical reactions. What's more, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) can be synthesized via the transesterification of EC and methanol generating ethylene glycol (EG), and EG is also used as the raw material of urea alcoholysis, therefore, this process is atom economical and desirable [7,12]. The broad applications of carbonates and their increasing demand necessitate the development of numerous methods for direct or indirect CO2 utilization. In particular, boosting the growth of the urea alcoholysis reaction can improve the industry chains of CO2. It would play an indispensable role in a sustainable and low-carbon economy [13,14]. Various metal-based catalysts have been successfully proposed for the transformation of urea and diols into cyclic carbonates [7,15–22]. Although significant progress has been made, some disadvantages are still needed to be overcome, especially it is difficult for conventional metal salt catalysts in presence of efficient catalytic activity to realize the green sustainability requirements with less metal-containing catalyst dosage at lower diols/urea molar ratio conditions. For instance, Kuznetsov et al. [23] proposed a zinc chloride-urea-EG homogeneous catalytic system. With the presence of a similar molar quantity for zinc chloride-urea-EG, they obtained the EC sample with the yield of 80%. Nevertheless, it would not be ideal for the abundant metallic catalytic process because it would cause environmental problems and corrosion. Zhao et al. [15] presented a zinc acetate catalyst (2.7% mol urea) to obtain propylene carbonate with the highest yield of 94% at higher molar ratio of urea to propylene glycol (1:4). However, such diols/urea molar ratio are not suitable for practical application due to the time and energy consumption for the separation of excessive diols. Since conventional metal salt catalysts have established structures and the upper limit of adjustable catalytic activity. To realize highly efficient catalytic activity with the less metal-containing catalyst at low diols, the environmentally greener organocatalytic systems have attracted increasing attention for the urea alcoholysis reaction. Ionic liquids (ILs) can be regarded as green organocatalytic systems on account of their excellent solubility, less pollution, high thermal stability, and adjustable structures, which allow for catalyst development and are identified as promising substitutes for conventional metal salt catalysts [24–27]. In addition, the Lewis acid (LA) centers of catalyst should act as an electrophilic reagent for activating the carbonyl carbon of urea (intermediate), which was a critical process for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates based on the transesterification mechanism of urea with diols [21,28]. Satisfactorily, the ILs also represent Lewis acidity by the coordination of inorganic metal ions, which could conform to the abovementioned prerequisites, but thus far, it has not been investigated for catalyzing this reaction. Simultaneously, introducing of a side chain for ILs can adjust the microenvironment of the catalytic active centers to regulate reactant molecular diffusion and LA distribution in the reaction system broadening the medium applications [29,30]. As a result, it is expected to realize the booting of the LA center through the regulation of the IL side chain and achieve efficient catalytic activity for the alcoholysis of urea with less metal-containing catalyst dosage at low diols/urea molar ratio. Herein, different chain lengths ILs with LA center as highly efficient catalytic system to synthesize EC from urea alcoholysis were demonstrated in this work. Firstly, ILs with different cations and anions were used (Scheme 1b) to find out the effect of boosting the LA center on this reaction. And the materials were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermogravimetric characterization analysis (TGA), 1H NMR and ESI. By utilizing MD simulation and pyridine probing FT-IR, the effect of the cationic structures of imidazolium-based ILs on the difference in anionic speciation and Lewis acidity was discussed. Moreover, the effect of catalytic performance was successively investigated and reaction conditions were optimized. Accordingly, the stability and suitability for different diols of optimal catalyst were tested. Based on the experimental results and DFT calculations, a possible anion-cation synergistic catalytic mechanism of EC synthesis with LA center ILs as the catalytic medium was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of IL systems The dried ILs (Scheme 1b) were acquired in a three-necked flask, then weighed, and the corresponding molar ratios of the metal chlorides (ZnCl2, CuCl2, FeCl3, MgCl2) were added into the three-necked flask and mixed thoroughly with the ILs. The mixture was reacted at 80 °C for about 8 h in a nitrogen atmosphere to obtain the Lewis acid center ILs [31]. 2.2 The procedure of synthesizing cyclic carbonates from urea alcoholysis The reaction of urea alcoholysis was conducted in an oil bath under magnetic stirring. The raw materials and a certain molar ratio of IL catalysts were added into a 50 mL three-necked flask. The flask was equipped with a reflux condenser and an ammonia absorption device. The ammonia gas that was generated during the reaction was absorbed by the ammonia absorption device through the serpentine condenser, and the absorption device was connected to a vacuum pump to ensure that the ammonia gas was discharged with enough time to promote the reaction. After the reaction, the mixture was cooled at room temperature and analyzed by an Agilent Technologies 7890 GC-TCD gas chromatograph. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterization and thermal stability of the ILs FT-IR spectras were obtained to further research the differences of the four ILs/2ZnCl2 (Fig. 1 a). Compared with single ILs (Fig. S1), the absorption peak at 2014 cm−1 for ILs/2ZnCl2 disappeared because the Cl− in the ILs combined with metal chloride, forming a new anion, MClx−. The new MClx− anion interacted with the imidazole cation, and the absorption peaks for the chemical bonds in the cation shifted [32]. However, it was clearly observed that the peaks at 1168 cm−1, 1107 cm−1, 1619 and 1568 cm−1 were the C-H, C-N, C=C and C=N bonds of the imidazole ring in both ILs and ILs/2ZnCl2, respectively [33]. Thus, the characteristic peaks of the imidazole ring were well preserved for ILs/2ZnCl2. The cationic structures of OmimCl and OmimCl/2ZnCl2 were identified by 1H NMR (Figs. 1b and S2), illustrating that the cationic structures of OmimCl and OmimCl/2ZnCl2 were similar, but the chemical shifts of the proton hydrogen differed. The active hydrogen signal of OmimCl/2ZnCl2 shifted to a higher field compared with OmimCl, as the ZnCl2 weakened the hydrogen bonds between the active hydrogen and the anion Cl atom, thereby improving the shielding effect of the active hydrogen [31,34]. Furthermore, the shifting active hydrogen signal reflects that the hydrogen bonding role of C(2)-H in the imidazole ring is easier formed with reaction substrate. The thermal stability of the IL system was investigated by TGA (Fig. 1c), the weight loss as a function of temperature was caused by the initial decomposition of the ILs/2ZnCl2 that appeared at 370 °C. This indicated that the ILs/2ZnCl2 had good thermal stability when compared with the initial thermal decomposition temperature of single ILs [28]. In addition, the reaction temperature of the urea alcoholysis process was generally less than 200 °C, which was much lower than the decomposition temperature of ILs. Therefore, the IL catalysts would not decompose during the catalytic reaction process, ensuring thermal stability. 3.2 Anionic speciation and MD calculation of ILs/2ZnCl2 Anionic mass spectrometry of the ILs/2ZnCl2 systems was conducted to confirm the anionic structure (Fig. 2 a), the most intensive peak was m/z 170.8, which corresponded to [ZnCl3]−. Only when the cation of ILs/2ZnCl2 was Omim+, did the dinuclear anion of [Zn2Cl5]− appear at m/z 306.7, and all data were listed in the literature [31,35]. Such anionic speciation was consistent with forming MClx− from FT-IR for ILs/2ZnCl2 systems. According to previous reports [36], the various forms of active anionic speciation in IL catalysts were important for the catalytic reaction. In this study, the results of ESI and experiment also displayed that the two dominant anion speciation, [ZnCl3]− and [Zn2Cl5]−, could influence the catalytic activity in this reaction. Thus, in order to prove that the cation chain lengths of imidazolium-based ILs could regulate the anionic speciation, MD simulation was used to explore the transformation process. For these, 50 pairs of IL and 100 pairs of ZnCl2 were chosen to simulate the synthesis process (the molar ratio of IL and ZnCl2 was 1:2) and the MD model in Fig. S3. Then, the interaction energy among ZnCl2 illustrated that the formation of aggregated clusters of ZnCl2 interacted more easily with OmimCl to obtain [Zn2Cl5]− (Fig. 2b). In addition, the SDFs of ZnCl2 around the cations of different ILs was exhibited in Fig. 2c–f. It indicated the amount of ZnCl2 around the Omim+ cation with maximum because the inductive effect of ILs cation had important influences on the synthesis of [Zn2Cl5]−. Therefore, the different side chain lengths had an obvious impact on the anionic speciation. 3.3 Catalytic activity for urea alcoholysis 3.3.1 Catalytic activity of ILs with different side chains Herein, IL catalysts were proposed for the alcoholysis of urea, where the Zn-based metal salts acted as the metal source. The ILs/2ZnCl2 catalytic system mainly included imidazole cations with different side chains. Under the same reaction conditions, the catalytic preformance of ILs for urea alcoholysis was evaluated (Fig. 3 a). For the IL catalysts with different side chain lengths, the yield and selectivity of EC initially improved with increased alkyl chain lengths in the cation, obeying the order of Omim+ > Bmim+ > Emim+. The results indicated that ILs with moderate cation chain length were beneficial for improving catalytic activity, and the results were consistent with the reported rule for epoxy addition reactions [37,38]. However, catalytic performance decreased when the alkyl chain length continued to increase (Omim+ > C12mim+ > C16mim+). This result was attributed to the alkyl chain of ILs was greater than that of Omim+, the alkyl chain exhibited hydrophobicity and the long-chain cation easily formed clusters [39], which was not conducive to the interactions with EG and urea. Moreover, the Lewis acidity of [Omim]Cl/2ZnCl2 was stronger than that of other alkyl ILs by pyridine probing FT-IR (Fig. 3b) and the anionic speciation with the cation chain lengths reflected the Lewis acidity strength of ILs. Thus, different anionic speciations from ESI (Fig. 2a) might be the main active group [40]. The results of DFT calculations, given below, could verify the abovementioned deduction that the LA center of [Zn2Cl5]− shown a stronger effect on urea than [ZnCl3]−. Therefore, the existence of [Zn2Cl5]− in OmimCl/2ZnCl2 could improve acidity and catalytic activity. Beside that, ILs with different functional groups have little effect on catalytic activity. Next, further investigations were carried out using the OmimCl/2MClx catalyst. 3.3.2 Catalytic activity of different Lewis acid center ILs It is generally believed that an urea alcoholysis catalyst should possess Lewis acid center [21,41]. The ILs exhibited Lewis acidity when OmimCl was mixed with metal chlorides at a proper molar ratio. Therefore, a series of OmimCl/2MClx were prepared and applied to the urea and EG reaction (Fig. 4 ), which showed that the addition of ILs significantly improved the yield and selectivity of EC. The increasing trend was OmimCl/2CuCl2 < OmimCl/2FeCl3 < OmimCl/2MgCl2 < OmimCl/2ZnCl2. Furthermore, the structure of different metal ions was confirmed by ESI (Fig. S4), and the results showed that all the four types of ILs had Lewis acid sites by pyridine probing FT-IR (Fig. S5), the LA center could also be arranged in the following order OmimCl/2MgCl2 < OmimCl/2CuCl2 < OmimCl/2FeCl3 < OmimCl/2ZnCl2. This was not consistent with the catalytic activity results, as Bronsted acid was present in OmimCl/2CuCl2 and OmimCl/2FeCl3, which affected and lowered catalytic activity. Therefore, the catalytic performance of the ILs was related to the number of Lewis acid sites, which is also consistent with the conclusion in Fig. 2 [30,36]. 3.3.3 Effect of catalysts composition and different anion types It have been reported that the Lewis acid center prepared from ZnCl2 and ILs can be significantly changed by varying the molar ratio of IL/nZnCl2, and the content of ZnCl2 affects the Lewis acidity of ILs [30,32]. Taking this into consideration, IL/nZnCl2 may possess a suitable combination of Lewis acids for alcoholysis of urea. To determine the optimal molar ratio of ILs and ZnCl2, the influence of the synthetic OmimCl/nZnCl2 catalysts composed of ILs and ZnCl2 in the reaction of urea and EG were evaluated (Fig. 5 a). When OmimCl and ZnCl2 were used separately, their catalytic activity was negligible. However, the catalyst obtained by reacting OmimCl with twice the amount of ZnCl2 exhibited higher activity and the presence of LA center [Zn2Cl5]− displayed a Lewis acid effect, which was helpful in increasing reaction activity (Fig. S6). Additionally, ESI (Fig. 5b) and the reaction activity result further confirmed that the presence of LA center [Zn2Cl5]− could promote the process of urea alcoholysis for product formation. 3.3.4 Optimization of reaction conditions The impacts of several parameters on the urea alcoholysis reaction, such as reaction temperature, pressure, reaction time, catalyst dosage, and the molar ratio of reactant, were studied in order to find the best reaction conditions for the OmimCl/2ZnCl2 catalytic system. were explored, and the optimal reaction conditions were determined. The yield and selectivity of the OmimCl/2ZnCl2 catalyst under different parameters were shown in Fig. 6 . As depicted in Fig. 6a, the effects of OmimCl/2ZnCl2 on the reaction at different temperatures. It was difficult for intermediate substance to convert EC under the lower reaction temperature, so the yield was low. And the concentration of intermediate substance was high under that reaction conditons resulted in the selectivity of EC was also low. With increasing reaction temperature, the selectivity and yield of EC increased gradually, and the highest yield of EC was 92.7% at 170 °C, but the effect was similar to that of EC at 160 °C. Typically, increasing the temperature shortens the time for a reaction to reach equilibrium. However, the too high reaction temperature might cause side reactions, which made the yield of EC increase not noticeable or even decrease [6,41]. Therefore, the optimal reaction temperature was 160 °C and OmimCl/2ZnCl2 will not decompose under the temperature from the result of TGA in Fig. 1c. The reaction pressure had an important effect on the reaction movement in the reaction system. Fig. 6b shown the effects of different reaction pressures on EC yield at 160 °C. According to the result, the highest yield of EC was 94.6% when the reaction pressure was 20 KPa. When the pressure was too low, the reactants concentration was reduced because they were easily extracted to obtain a low yield of EC. Apart from NH3, water was also removed in time to improve the conversion rate of intermediate substance to another by-product (2-Oxazolidone) under that reaction pressure, which resulted in the lower selectivity of EC. And the yield of the EC would decrease when the reaction pressure exceeded 20 KPa. On account of the ammonia generated from the reaction, it was difficultly removed from the urea alcoholysis process with sufficient time when the vacuum of the system was too high, which reduced the equilibrium conversion of this reaction [28]. As shown in Fig. 6c, the selectivity and yield of the EC reached a maximum at 2 h and then decreased slightly with extended reaction time. When the reaction time was prolonged to 3 h, the yield of EC decreased slightly, which may have been related to the weight loss of the reaction system. The reaction was insufficient for intermediate substance to completely transform into EC when the reaction time was shorter, therefore, the yield and selectivity of the EC were low. It was also possible that the reaction achieved equilibrium after 2 h, and the EC yield reached its maximum. Under continuous vacuum pumping conditions, some reactants were also removed from the reaction. Therefore, the yield of the product decreased during the process after calculating the product yield. The selectivity droped quickly with the prolonging of the reaction time because of the increase of 2-Oxazolidone and deep side reactions such as the polymerization of EC and the ethylene oxide formation of EC decomposition [6,15,41]. All the results are displayed in Fig. 6d about the effects of catalyst amount on the reaction. Under the catalysis of OmimCl/2ZnCl2, the reaction rate of EC increased rapidly. This proved that OmimCl/2ZnCl2 played an important catalytic role in urea alcoholysis. The selectivity and yield of EC also increased with mounting catalyst dosage. When the catalyst amount was 1% mol, the EC yield decreased, indicating that lower amounts of catalyst did not fully meet the requirements for the urea alcoholysis reaction to form EC. And this was not conducive to the conversion of intermediate substance, so the selectivity was low. When the catalyst amount was 2% mol, the catalytic reaction achieved its best state, and further increases in catalyst quantity did not significantly affect the reaction [6,17]. And the catalytic activity of LA center IL was much higher than that of ZnCl2 alone although the use of metal salt was reduced by half (Fig. 5a), this also indicated that the construction of LA center ILs could ensure high catalytic activity with low metal salts dosage. As displayed in Fig. 6e, the yield and selectivity of EC increased gradually with increasing molar ratios of EG to urea and reached its maximum when the molar ratio was 1:2. Compared with previous reports [15,28], the diols/urea molar ratio has been reduced by half, which explained the LA center ILs catalyst had a certain strengthening effect at low diols/urea molar ratio. Furthermore, the yield and selectivity of EC declined as the molar ratio of the raw materials rose, possibly because of the low urea content and slow reaction efficiency. At the same time, the concentration of EG was high when the molar ratio increased, and the ammonia generated by the reaction had greater solubility because of the high viscosity of EG. It prevented the sufficient removal of ammonia, which also affected the equilibrium conversion of the reaction and resulted in a decline in EC yield. This reason also caused the increase of the content of intermediate substance, therefore, the selectivity of EC was decreased [15,42]. 3.4 Catalyst recycling The catalyst of OmimCl/2ZnCl2 was chosen for the recycling reaction to verify catalytic recycling as a function of EC yield and selectivity, and thereby establish the stability of catalyst. Vacuum distillation was utilized to separate the products and the OmimCl/2ZnCl2 after each cycle, the obtaining OmimCl/2ZnCl2 was recycled for the reaction. Then catalyst mixture was recycled for the synthetic reaction and the catalytic activity only decreased by 20% after 14 cycles (Fig. 7 ). For reported MgTiO3 catalyst in this reaction [16], the catalytic activity would be decreased nearly 30% after 4 cycles, demonstrating that the OmimCl/2ZnCl2 catalyst could be recycled. The molecular weights of the OmimCl/2ZnCl2 catalyst were measured before and after runs by ESI (Fig. S7a and b). The [Zn2Cl5] − anion disappeared, but the new molecular weight of cation was obtained (m/z 171.0) and the Omim+ was maintained (m/z 195.1) after 12 runs. The appearance of m/z 171.0 ([194–23]+) might be the molecular weight of a new substance formed by the loss of hydrogen for the imidazole cation of C(2)-H [43] (m/z 194.0 minus the relative atomic mass of sodium m/z 23.0) during recycling in cation mode detecting for ESI-MS. At the same time, the color change of the recycling ILs (recycled-1, recycled-3, recycled-6, recycled-9 and recycled-11), indicating a part of ILs were carbonized in the recycling process in Fig. S7c. Both of the these all shown the cationic of Omin+ was also changed. This would explain the changes in cations and anions would lead to decreased catalytic activity, which further indicated that cations and anions would have a synergistic effect on the catalytic reaction [28,44]. 3.5 Reaction process and DFT calculations According to the previous reports [6,17,19,28,45], it could be found there were two steps for urea alcoholysis. The first step was the nucleophilic addition of EG and urea, which produced hydroxyethyl carbamate (HEC) while releasing a molecule of ammonia. Then, when the elimination of ammonia from HEC, it could generate EC by self cyclization reaction. Therefore, the reaction process for urea alcoholysis to synthesize EC was proposed as follows (Scheme 2). In order to further verify reaction process was correct, ESI-MS analysis was carried out on the product after 1 h of reaction under the reaction conditions (160 °C, 20 KPa, urea:EG (mol:mol)=1:2, 2% mol (urea) catalyst), which showed the reaction process was divided into two steps. And the intermediate substance (HEC) appeared in this process (Fig. S8). From previous reported that the LA center can activate the carbonyl groups of urea and HEC to promote EC formation [6,28]. Combining the ESI, pyridine probing FT-IR and experimental results further proved that different anionic speciation had important effects on the reaction. Therefore, DFT calculations were performed to verify the detailed interactions between OmimCl/2ZnCl2 ([Omim][ZnCl3] or [Omim][Zn2Cl5]) and urea (HEC). The interaction between C=O group of urea and Zn2+ of [Omim][Zn2Cl5] for complex energy, which was higher than [Omim][ZnCl3] from −35.3 to −51.0 Kcal/mol (Fig. 8 a and b). The C=O (HEC) group interaction's complex energy followed the same pattern from −33.0 to −45.5 Kcal/mol (Fig. 8c and d). Thus, by comparing the interaction energies, it further verified that LA center [Zn2Cl5]− could more effectively promote the reaction, and these were consistent with the above pyridine probing FT-IR and experimental results. Additionally, the electrophilicity of the C in the C=O group for urea/HEC was altered from 0.815/0.949 to 0.826/0.975 when they complexed with [Omim][ZnCl3] and [Omim][Zn2Cl5], respectively. This caused the electrophilicity of the carbon atom in C=O for urea/HEC to become stronger, making the C in C=O more susceptible to attack (Tables 1 and S9 in supporting information) [40]. Notably, the structure of OmimCl/2ZnCl2 changed after the catalyst was recycled and combined with previous reports [28,46,47], there was a synergistic effect between the cation and anion in ILs. DFT simulation results explained that C(2)-H of imidazolium cation could show H-bonds role with the hydroxyl of EG/HEC and C(2)-H in the imidazole ring is easier formed with reaction substrate from 1H NMR for the cationic structures of OmimCl and OmimCl/2ZnCl2. The complex energy of C(2)-H and EG (HEC) were −11.5 Kcal/mol and −10.8 Kcal/mol in Fig. 8e and 8g, respectively. Moreover, when the cation and anion of [Omim][Zn2Cl5] could catalyze with different sites of both urea and EG (HEC) cooperatively, the complex energy could lower between them compare with [Omim][Zn2Cl5] activated at a single reactant site, from −51.0 and −11.5 Kcal/mol (−45.5 and −10.8 Kcal/mol) to −65.3 Kcal/mol (−52.1 Kcal/mol), as shown in Fig. 8f and h. At the same time, the electrophilicity of the C in the C=O group of urea and the O in the H-O group of EG were further altered from 0.826/−0.574 to 0.831/−0.582 when urea and EG both complexed with [Omim][Zn2Cl5], respectively. (Tables 1, 2 and S9 in supporting information), and the same changes have occurred in HEC. This further confirmed that a synergistic effect between the cations and anions for OmimCl/2ZnCl2 catalyst, and this result was consistent with the abovementioned experimental results. 3.6 Catalytic mechanism By comparing and analyzing the characterization, experimental results and DFT calculations, a relationship between the structure and performance of the ILs could be ascertained, which indicated two reasons for OmimCl/2ZnCl2 exhibiting higher catalytic efficiency and stability. First, LA center in OmimCl/2ZnCl2, which was beneficial for interactions between the ILs and the reactive molecules (urea and HEC) for facilitating the reaction. And this conclusion has been reported in these literatures [21,45]. Second, the prepared ILs exerted catalytic properties on the reaction process, which was mainly due to the synergistic catalytic effects of the IL catalyst between the anion and cation [28,44]. Based on the above analysis, the reaction mechanism was formulated, as shown in Scheme 3 . The Lewis acidity center could activate the urea carbonyl oxygen atom, and the C(2)-H of the imidazole cation and could form a hydrogen bond with EG, forming the intermediate substance (HEC) and ammonia (Step 1). Then, HEC completed the self cyclization process in the presence of the catalyst, synthesizing ethylene carbonate (Step 2). 3.7 Catalytic activity for urea and other diols To better understand and compare the reactions of urea with other diols, the effects of the reactions of urea with different diols (1,2-propylene glycol, 1,2-butylene glycol, 1-phenylethane-1,2-diol, 1,3-propanediol, and 1,3-butanediol) on the synthesis of corresponding cyclic carbonates were investigated using OmimCl/ZnCl2 as the catalyst. Table 3 presents the synthesis results that corresponded to the cyclic carbonates by the reaction of urea with different diols. After comparing the yield of the cyclic carbonates, we found the distinct three-dimensional structure between 1,2-diol and 1,3-diol caused the differences for these yields of cyclic carbonates [17]. The high viscosity of the three hydroxyl oxygen atoms of glycerol, which affected the mass transfer of the reaction process and the corresponding yield of glyceryl carbonate, was only 38.1%. In addition, the yield of 1-phenylethane-1,2-diol was reduced due to the effects of molecular steric hindrance [48]. 4 Conclusion In summary, an efficient catalytic and eco-friendly ILs system was developed for the reaction between urea and diols under mild conditions. The catalytic system comprising the IL of [Omim]Cl/2ZnCl2 exhibited excellent reusability and generality, the yield and selectivity of EC reached 96% and 98%, respectively. And it was illustrated that the inductive influence of cation in ILs had important influences on the synthesis of [Zn2Cl5]−. Additionally, according to the experimental results and DFT calculations, it could be confirmed that the measured lengths of IL cations affected the presence of LA center and an IL anion-cation synergistic catalytic mechanism had been proposed, which illustrates that urea and EG are both induced by the IL catalyst, thus enhancing the highly efficient synthesis of EC. To be specific, this catalytic system showed excellent performance even with less metal-containing catalyst at lower diols/urea molar ratio. Thus, this research provides a theoretical basis for the subsequent designing of more efficient catalysts for conversion of urea into cyclic carbonates through a green and sustainable synthetic pathway. coredata.dc:description: Synthesis of cyclic carbonates from cheap and reusable urea is of great importance, but it is still an immense challenge to obtain highly efficient catalysts using relatively less metal-containing catalysts for this route due to conventional metal salt catalysts with established structure. Herein, a series of eco-friendly ionic liquids (ILs) with different cationic structures were adopted as efficient catalysts for the reaction of urea alcoholysis. By regulating the cation chain lengths, different lewis acid centers of imidazolium-based ILs with chain lengths from C2 to C16 were constructed. The IL with a moderate side chain (OmimCl/ZnCl2) exhibited better catalytic performance and the yield of ethylene carbonate (EC) could reach 96% percent with less metal-containing catalyst at lower diols/urea molar ratio conditions. Through exploring the structure-activity relationships of cationic structure and anionic speciation, it was illustrated that the inductive effect of cation in ILs had important influences on the synthesis of [Zn2Cl5]−. Additionally, the appearance of the [Zn2Cl5]−, which has been proved with pyridine spectroscopic could strengthen the lewis acidity of ILs to obtain high catalytic activity, this could avoid excessive metal-containing in ILs. Based on the experimental results and DFT calculations, an IL anion-cation synergistic catalytic mechanism has been proposed. Thus, the use of ILs opens up a new green avenue and provides a preliminary basis of CO2 utilization.
coredata.dc:title: Tunable imidazolium ionic liquids as efficient catalysts for conversion of urea into cyclic carbonates
